I switched over to Strava because of the rave reviews. Sadly I came to find out that it‚Äôs functionality and challenges are a joke. I run an IPhone 7 (updated) and an Apple watch 3 (updated). It is not at all intuitive, is less accurate than any other running app I‚Äôve used and the worst part is the Share setting. It is automatically enabled to the Everyone setting and there is no way to know that, until you inadvertently post your first run by saving it.

I‚Äôm coming back from an injury and am currently so slow I can‚Äôt keep up with my running group. Just getting out and moving again is a painful challenge and seeing my worst times posted for all the world to see made me want to give up rather than keep going.

 Fast or slow I‚Äôm not a person who likes to announce all of my activities to the world but this app only allows workouts to ‚Äúcount‚Äù toward challenges if they are posted for everyone to see. I couldn‚Äôt stomach it so I made most of my runs private and only posted enough to keep participating with my friends. I think the creators of this app should really reconsider if posting publicly should be a requirement to participate in challenges. Why does my effort only ‚Äúcount‚Äù if I brag about it? Shouldn‚Äôt it be enough for me to work privately to reach a personal goal? If my followers don‚Äôt see my run, did I even get off my couch?Strava consistently records inaccurate data. Strava reports almost mile times almost 90 seconds early. Every. Single. Time. When I‚Äôve repeatedly contacted support there is no real response besides a canned message that I ‚Äúbad gps data‚Äù or my phone is the problem... yet if I run with both Mapmyrun and Strava  open, pulling from same GPS signal, the free app has no inaccuracies and actually gives me correct info. The GPS inaccuracy is a known issue and it‚Äôs crazy to me that Strava has the gall to charge so much without support or response. I love the challenges and interface, however, reliability for accurate times is a non-negotiable.

Do better at supporting your pricey app and responding to your customer.Strava only has an iPhone app in the Apple store. It will run in 1/4 your screen, or blown up and pixelated as if it were a fisher price toy.
If you go to Strava  using Safari on your iPad, it will fail to render properly - most significantly it will not display notifications or challenges. There are other bits missing,  but those are the two I noticed. It will place a banner at the top of the page telling you to get the iPad app, but that is a lie... you will get an iPhone app.  Additionally requesting the mobile or desktop version of the website will not fix the problem. You either will be blind on notifications or you will curse and go to your desktop/laptop and log in there.The intrusive, never ending pop up ads for ‚Äúfeatures‚Äù are really killing this app. Strava, I knew about the personal group challenges when you announced them. I‚Äôve actually started one. I don‚Äôt need an interruptive full screen ad for one every 3rd time I use the app to quickly change a setting or entry. It‚Äôs infuriating. I paid for your overprice premium membership (although I‚Äôm not going to be renewing that). Just let me use the app. If you want to add features, give us parity with the website instead of the app which has been crippled for years.Strava doesn‚Äôt allow anyone to edit activities. They say this is because people would cheat on challenges and segments. 
That is a ridiculous policy for many reasons:
1. Some people forget to stop their watch/app at the end of their workout, so it logs their car ride home as part of the workout. 
2. GPS is often wildly inaccurate on small courses, like a track, where counting laps is much more accurate. 
3. Treadmill and spin workouts already don‚Äôt count towards challenges (or segments). This means the app/website already has the ability to exclude data from challenges. So make edited workouts work the same way. 

Strava‚Äôs one job is to be an accurate activity log. If it can‚Äôt do that, it‚Äôs worthless. 

Still, deserves one star (not zero) because the UI is nice, and the segments are a nice way to race the neighbors or find neat spots when traveling.
